Award.AwardTitle: CPS/Synergy/Collaborative Research: Cybernizing Mechanical Structures through Integrated Sensor-Structure Fabrication

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The timely and accurate in-service identification of faults in mechanical structures, such as airplanes, can play a vitally important role in avoiding catastrophes. One major challenge, however, is that the sensing system relies on high frequency signals, the coordination of which is difficult to achieve throughout a large structure. To tackle this fundamental issue, the research team will take advantage of 3D printing technology to fabricate integrated sensor-structure components. Specifically, the team plans to innovate a novel printing scheme that can embed piezoelectric transducers (namely, sensor/actuator coupled elements) into layered composites. As the transducers are densely distributed throughout the entire structure, they function like a nerve system embedded into the structure. Such a sensor nerve system, when combined with new control and command systems and advanced data and signal processing capability, can fully unleash the latest computing power to pinpoint the fault location.

The new framework of utilizing emerging additive manufacturing technology to produce a structural system with integrated, densely distributed active sensing elements will potentially lead to paradigm-shifting progress in structural self-diagnosis. This advancement may allow the acquisition of high-quality, active interrogation data throughout the entire structure, which can then be used to facilitate highly accurate and robust decision-making. It will lead to intellectual contributions including: 1) development of a new sensing modality with mechanical-electrical dual-field adaptivity, that yields rich and high-quality data throughout the structure; 2) design of an additive manufacturing scheme that inserts piezoelectric micro transducer arrays throughout the structure to enable active interrogation; and 3) formulation of new data analytics and inverse analysis that can accurately identify the fault location/severity and guide the fine-tuning of the sensor system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The timely and accurate detection and identification of structural faults during their operations can play a vitally important role in ensuring the safety and sustainability of various structural systems in aerospace, marine, transportation and infrastructure, and energy and power industries. The diagnosis information can further guide the realization of autonomous systems that are capable of functioning adaptively upon their current healthy status. Such a mission, however, is inherently difficult, because structural faults/degradations usually have extremely small characteristic lengths with infinitely many possible patterns/profiles. In this collaborative research by University of Connecticut (UConn), Georgia Institute of Technology (GT), and Texas A&M University (TAMU), our vision is to create a new framework of cybernizing structural system for self-diagnosis (Figure 1). This framework is enabled by the emerging additive manufacturing technology that can produce a structural system inserted with densely distributed active sensing elements analogous to nerves, and encompasses paradigm-shifting advancements in three inter-related fronts: 1) synthesis of new sensing modality with dual-field adaptivity, that yields rich and high-quality interrogation data; 2) design and demonstration of new fabrication scheme that directly inserts sensing nerves throughout the structure; and 3) formulation of new data analytics and inverse analysis that takes full advantage of the rich data to predict fault occurrence with high accuracy and robustness. This framework, through the novel sensory nerve system, effectively connects a physical structure with the cyber space, which will lead to unprecedented progress in real-time structural diagnosis. This project features the synergistic efforts in distributed sensory system, additive manufacturing, and data analytics.

The GT research team focused on ink materials investigation and optimization, and design/simulation and fabrication of the P(VDF-TrFE) actuator-sensor arrays for the CPS project. An advanced additive manufacturing process, Aerosol Jet printing (AJP), is investigated and employed to fabricate the transducers. The simulation and experimental results from this project demonstrated the feasibility and potential for P(VDF-TrFE) actuator-sensor arrays for structural health monitoring applications.

This project has helped establish new knowledge for solving challenging problems related to better understanding of additive manufacturing of transducers for structural health monitoring applications. The developed AJP manufacturing process and models can help improve the future applications of structural damage detection with embedded transducers. The outcome of the project can also trigger the wide application of cybernized structural systems in a variety of industries, such as aerospace, transportation, infrastructure, and power/energy. From this project, broader impacts to the society are achieved through a series of activities at the three partnering universities to benefit undergraduate and graduate students as well as the related research communities and industries. Meanwhile, the collaborative nature of this research provided students with a multidisciplinary training experience. A specific example of the broader impact of the project at GT is the training of veterans students in this emerging research field through a collaboration with an NSF REU Site program, Research Experience for Student Veterans in Advanced Manufacturing and EntrePreneurship (REVAMP). Figure 2 shows student cohort (five were veterans) who participated in 2019 REVAMP REU at GT.
